Over the past two weeks, we have reflected on how to best use our social media channels at this time. We are listening and learning from our colleagues, and will be sharing their perspectives on works from the Gallery’s collection.

We’re putting aside our daily tours to spend some time thinking how we can best use our social media platforms going forward. While we work to discuss this internally, we’d like to hear from you—how can we best serve you? Let us know here or by emailing socialmedia@nga.gov. (6/6)

"Our past does not have to be our destiny. We must let the power of art, which is the power of all that we share as human beings, be a power that prevails through this difficult time." (5/6)

https://t.co/r7eGRSYAAe

“We mourn for our fellow Americans George Floyd, Ahmaud Arbery, Breonna Taylor, Tony McDade, their families, and many others because our shared humanity ties us to them. Those same ties must now bring us together for a more just and equitable future.” (4/6)
“That lesson of art seems particularly important now, when so many are suffering, not only because of the global pandemic but also because of longstanding and deep-rooted racism.” (3/6)

“Invariably, our encounters with art leave us more complete because they remind us of our shared humanity. We are part of something more profound than just ourselves. Our lives have meaning because of that basic truth.” (2/6)

From Director @KaywinFeldman:

“Many of us look at art to see beauty and triumph, to find peace, and to be uplifted. But art offers the full range of the human experience, and it may just as readily show us ugliness, suffering, aggression, injustice, and tragedy.” (1/6)
For today’s #MuseumMomentofZen, a detail of Rembrandt’s “An Old Lady with a Book” from 1637. https://t.co/iFwJlCfmK7

Thanks for following along on today’s tour of gallery 48. 

The Gallery has a deep collection of works by Rembrandt—we’ll discuss his paintings of mythological and biblical stories, on view in the neighboring gallery 51, in a future tour. https://t.co/bvcrK2yuL7

The penetrating expression of “A Polish Nobleman” and the striking resemblance of his features to Rembrandt’s, particularly in the area around the eyes and nose, make one wonder if this painting is not, in fact, a fanciful and liberally embellished self-portrait. https://t.co/6ouLoTCgIs

The brown collar and reddish-brown sleeve of the jacket are painted thinly to suggest the softer feel of fur and cloth. To create the texture of the beaver hat, Rembrandt scratched the surface with the butt end of his brush. https://t.co/0xVjzVzIJK

Painted on a single, large oak panel, this work is well preserved. Rembrandt’s use of impasto (thickly applied paint) on the face reinforces the three-dimensional presence of the image.

Impastos also accent the gold medallion. https://t.co/1dIvE3xm2S

His confident stance as he grasps a gold-topped wooden staff, his broad mustache, and the gold chain and medallion that hang over the fur jacket give him an air of authority and grandeur.

The shaded eyes, furrowed brow, and partially opened mouth make him more approachable. https://t.co/Oloo39UeUm
As this imposing figure stares out beneath his tall beaver hat, he at once confronts the viewer with directness and draws us in with his introspective gaze. https://t.co/2tHkKGquHF

Though Rembrandt made many commissioned portraits, this is probably not a specific individual. Instead, it represents a more generic type that he favored in the 1630s. Such paintings allowed him to imaginatively expand the limits of portraiture. https://t.co/YuPkbRDtmn

Finally, we’ll look at “A Polish Nobleman” from 1637.  
 
With dramatic accents of light and dark on the face, bold brushwork, and dense application of paint, Rembrandt created a powerful, almost sculptural presence. https://t.co/ftnb2qBr5P

He looks out at us and confronts us directly. The complexity of human emotion conveyed through the eyes makes Rembrandt’s work still resonate today.  Our shared humanity is on full view, yet hard to pinpoint.  Is it sadness? Pensiveness? Humility? Confidence? https://t.co/SDML1yNrLL
Light also accents his left shoulder and clasped hands, but most of the painting is in dark shadow and loosely painted. https://t.co/UzbpbJWmvF

The light illuminates his head, drawing attention to his deep-set eyes, wrinkled cheeks, and furrowed brow. To create his scruffy grey hair, Rembrandt used the end of his paintbrush handle to scratch through the wet paint to make curls. https://t.co/YUONQnfxe2

Painted over the years, Rembrandt's self-portraits show him young and old, dressed in everyday clothes or wearing theatrical costumes and elegant hats. And some, such as the “Self-Portrait” of 1659, Rembrandt examines his identity as an artist. https://t.co/PWvDndZX3s
Compare these different self portraits, all in the Gallery’s collection. https://t.co/yHzzdFuCBr

In a way, Rembrandt was his own favorite model. He could experiment with different techniques and practice drawing facial expressions that convey different moods.

Rembrandt was 53 years old when he painted this self-portrait in 1659. https://t.co/PDZyv22MFZ

While Rembrandt didn’t paint many landscapes, the one “landscape” with which he was very familiar was the terrain of his own face. 

Rembrandt’s numerous painted, etched, and drawn self-portraits make him one of the most recognizable artists of his era. https://t.co/fXM7MzeMan

Rembrandt is known for his strong contrasts of light and dark. In “The Mill” he used light to feature some areas of picture, and left other parts in shadow. He used this technique, called chiaroscuro (from the Italian words for “light” and “dark”), in many of his portraits too. https://t.co/L1yp9XNLou
In the foreground, people are engaged in everyday activities: a woman washes clothes at the edge of the river, a fisherman rows home, and a woman walks with her child. https://t.co/XAg7VMrkL0
In “The Mill” Rembrandt places the windmill on a hill, its sails full, silhouetted against a cloudy sky. The sunlight breaking through after a storm. https://t.co/DAZ9MERXJw

But the image of the windmill may have been more personal for Rembrandt—his father owned a mill on the banks of the Old Rhine near Leiden.
 
The family derived its name from the mill, which was called “De Rijn” (Dutch for “the Rhine”). https://t.co/L0FR53EaPW

Windmills were also used to grind wheat, corn, and barley. Contributing to the country’s productivity, windmills became symbols of prosperity and national pride in the 17th century. https://t.co/C255MBHfbj

It’s hard to imagine the Dutch landscape without windmills. With much of the country below sea level, windmill power was used to drain the land of water so that it could be farmed. 

[“The Windmill,” 1641] https://t.co/mnPoW51hRu

The Gallery’s collection also includes some examples of Rembrandt’s landscape drawings and etchings.

[“View over the Amstel from the Rampart,” c. 1646/1650] https://t.co/L4iXUZGKj7
The painting does not depict a specific place, but instead is an imaginary scene that Rembrandt devised from his drawings and memory. https://t.co/5KSZFfWeY4

The first work we’ll look at is “The Mill” from 1645/1648.  
 
Although Rembrandt made many drawings and prints of landscapes throughout his life, he created few paintings of them—”The Mill” is his largest one. https://t.co/APX5qXoIGJ

Born in 1606 near Leiden, Rembrandt van Rijn moved to Amsterdam in 1632 where he quickly became one of the leading artists of the city and one of the most versatile artists of the 17th c.—exploring a range of portrait types, as well as history, mythological, and biblical subjects https://t.co/IRzZIx9peQ
Our tour is led (from home) by Nathalie Ryan (@seethinkwonder), a senior educator in the Gallery's division of education. https://t.co/ZVc0t2q6s4

Today we’re celebrating #Rembrandt with a tour of some of his paintings in gallery 48 on the Main Floor of the West Building. #MuseumFromHome
 
See all the works in the gallery: https://t.co/m1lekRcL3b https://t.co/Q7LV0LsfvE
@LydaAstrove What a lovely memory!
@tarheel5423 Sure! We'll look more at Homer's work in a future tour.
@MandaC976 We're glad.
@DrLindaTribuzio That's an interesting observation! The arc from the sail, through the boat, to the waves on the right does draw your eye.

We hope you’ve enjoyed this moment with one of Winslow Homer’s paintings and that it has brought you some peace.

Take another mindful moment with our earlier look at Edouard Vuillard’s “The Artist's Paint Box and Moss Roses” (1898).
https://t.co/GfzM587ckc

Reflect on your looking and imagining about “Breezing Up” today. What does this painting mean to you, today, in this moment? 

What do you hope to remember from this experience? https://t.co/uuBR1J46jS
When “Breezing Up” was exhibited in 1876, it delighted critics. They felt the painting’s energy, freshness, and orientation towards the horizon signified a sense of optimism. https://t.co/KUuoHE77NY

Slowly open your eyes. 

Take another look at the painting to see if anything looks differently. https://t.co/UZismui00k

Close your eyes or lower your gaze again, take a deep breath, and imagine you’re sailing on the boat. 

What sensations do you feel on your skin? What does the air smell like? What sounds do you hear? How do you feel? https://t.co/mu5vtuKoSM

Turn your attention to the figures on the boat. Observe their positions, postures, and expressions. 

What words would you use to describe the group? https://t.co/YV0npk7yJK

Take in this whole painting. Notice where your eyes go first, and where your gaze lingers. 

When you feel like you’ve seen everything, look for something you hadn’t noticed before. https://t.co/70FmdwOJQR

To begin: close your eyes or lower your gaze, and take a deep breath. Notice the sounds around you and the sensations you feel on your body. Notice your thoughts, and then do your best to set them aside for the moment. 

Open your eyes slowly.

While we hope our daily tours have offered you some respite during these difficult times, today our whole tour will be a #MuseumMomentofZen. 

We’ll take a mindful moment with the painting on the left—Winslow Homer’s “Breezing Up (A Fair Wind)” (1873-1876). #MuseumFromHome https://t.co/V92ddegiJm

Take a break and watch moments from past artist talks that resonate today as reminders of the richness and resilience of human expression: https://t.co/0a3txkvnY8

[“May Flowers,” 2002, printed 2013, ©Carrie Mae Weems. Courtesy of the artist and Jack Shainman Gallery, New York] https://t.co/JDR62oTRA3
@BainbridgeCons @stuartfowkes @royalacademy @Tate Here's something to hold you over for now. https://t.co/XdrJQX8kZQ
For today’s #MuseumMomentofZen, Ruth Asawa’s “Spring” from 1965. https://t.co/o2uNQS2WSn

Ruth Asawa’s life and work is an fine model of how, by forefronting your curiosity, actively observing and continually engaging with your surroundings—even those familiar to you—you can always discover something striking, that you didn’t quite notice or appreciate before. https://t.co/oxoHfU39aN

These two examples also resonate with the bulbous and branch-like forms found in Asawa’s wire sculptures, underscoring the important role her studies from nature play in shaping her artistic vocabulary. https://t.co/Z46NIMIlVV

While the glowing spherical form comprised of root-like networks ​and colored auras in “Desert Plant” calls to mind everything from a luminous planet, or a diagram of an eyeball with a hot red iris, to a dandelion gone to seed set against a blazing sun. https://t.co/t5lmJ1RE8n

She entertained a variety of stylistic approaches to the flower forms she undertook in the set. Repeating rows of outlined petals arranged in increasingly smaller concentric circles pull the viewer into the depths of the flower’s center in “Flowers II.” https://t.co/xv81jESjHr

Asawa worked with liquid tusche, a greasy pigmented liquid, in some of her lithographs to produce effects similar to watercolor or ink wash. She used it for this print of a purple iris, “Flowers V,” from a portfolio of 12 flower subjects she made during her fellowship. https://t.co/P0lfitaHZu
The viewer is equally swept up by the loving portrayals of these distinct individuals and dazzled by the lively linework that define their forms. https://t.co/CqquBsmK5b

Precise details, like the distinctive curve of a chin, are juxtaposed with networks of hatch marks that describe the pattern of a shirt or blanket, yet simultaneously have an life of their own, dissolving into energetic abstract lines of ink on the flat surface of the paper. https://t.co/HI9o347r29

Figural themes might surprise those only familiar with Asawa’s sculptures. However, Asawa possessed a remarkable ability to combine figural and abstract elements within the same work, as seen in 3 portraits of her sons, Hudson, Xavier, and Adam (sleeping by the family dog, Henry) https://t.co/BpLDxdKEB3

Her primary subjects were flowers—long a favored motif—rendered in various degrees of abstraction, and her family, whom she undoubtedly missed during her residency at Tamarind.

["Flowers XI," 1965] https://t.co/k0j8qCQwNz

The Gallery is fortunate to own a complete set of the remarkable 54 lithographs Asawa made during this time which demonstrate her impressive range of mark-making, interest in color, and adaptation to a new medium. https://t.co/gmtPcetvcb

In 1965, Asawa received a fellowship residency at the Tamarind Lithography Workshop in Los Angeles. She spent two months there embracing and experimenting with lithographic techniques (something she had not previously explored) under the guidance of skilled printers. https://t.co/aX0XYiPJIA

Asawa drew to explore artistic concepts as well as a way to continuously sharpen her observational skills.

["Haru," 1965] https://t.co/6F9H0TBn30

The wire provided a means of drawing in space. Drawing was a constant in Asawa’s life, from the time she was a young girl sketching plants and flowers on the family farm, during her internment, and throughout her career as an artist.

["Bud," 1965] https://t.co/PAOXfo7NbY

The method appealed to Asawa’s fascination with line, variation of pattern, and spatial relationships that grew out of her training in drawing and design at Black Mountain College.

["Plane Tree Reversal," 1965] https://t.co/wBq98t4Teb

Underlying the creation of Asawa’s 3D work, is the line of the wire that she manipulates to define forms and their resulting volumes. She adapted her technique from a “wire crochet” basket weaving practice using a single piece of wire that she learned on a visit to Mexico. https://t.co/z27mGrPDDj

Asawa is best known for transparent hanging sculptures of biomorphic forms: spheres within spheres, attenuated orb and tear-drop shapes that seem almost organically grown, exploring relationships between interior and exterior space.

[© Imogen Cunningham Trust, @smithsoniannpg] https://t.co/iskqQgthFc

According to her eldest daughter Aiko (seated on the left), “We always saw her making art, it was part of her everyday existence. I never thought of her making art as a separate activity. To us, she wasn’t working. We didn’t have to be quiet so she could concentrate." https://t.co/LViKrAvuou

Seated on the floor with head bowed, Asawa concentrates on looping wire to form one of her magnificent sculptures in the midst of four of her children. How I envy her ability to be so focused and yet so much a part of her environment! https://t.co/VwyTucCQ6j

There, Asawa’s artistic abilities became an integral practice of her daily life, and obstacles were regarded as curves in her path.

This photograph from 1957 by Asawa’s close friend and noted photographer, Imogen Cunningham, shows the artist at work.

[© Imogen Cunningham Trust] https://t.co/jPOhdYSAC2

A teacher suggested she pursue her artistic interests at the progressive Black Mountain College in North Carolina where there was no separation between studying, performing daily chores, and engaging with a variety of art forms. 

[1973 photo by Mimi Jacobs,” @ArchivesAmerArt] https://t.co/MIENGGkpzE

Asawa grew up on a working farm, lived in an internment camp for Japanese Americans during World War II, and was denied teaching jobs, due to post-war racial bias. 

Ruth Asawa internment camp ID, 1943, @smithsoniannpg https://t.co/AKGfiZJ9X4

Our tour is led (from home) by Shelley Langdale, curator and head of modern prints and drawings at the Gallery: “As many of us struggle to adapt to new challenges of working entirely from home, I find myself looking for inspirational examples, such as Ruth Asawa.” https://t.co/oSDM7sYpwL

As #AAPIHM comes to a close, today’s tour will celebrate the work of the groundbreaking artist, educator, and activist, Ruth Asawa. #MuseumFromHome

See all of the works by Asawa in the Gallery’s collection: https://t.co/LAbweHJ6gv https://t.co/N4pYK3DqPG

For today’s break, read a reflection by Robert Price, conservator for the French Sculpture Project, on touch in relation to his work in caring for and treating objects: https://t.co/X5kGKLro0v #NGAconservation https://t.co/x3icyr6AAJ
And for today’s #MuseumMomentofZen, imagine yourself sitting on the bank looking at the view of Claude Monet’s “The Bridge at Argenteuil” from 1874. https://t.co/f6wi5OCt2F

Also included in this gallery are works featuring a favorite impressionist subject—gardens. We’ll return to gallery 85 another day to look at the gardens painted by Monet, Renoir, and Caillebotte. https://t.co/NjoLpobHkA
Smaller, more densely painted strokes of color have given way to loosely applied, broader strokes in pastel hues. https://t.co/NsN4LuRCLn

Nearly 10 years had passed between these two versions of a young girl in a garden, one holding a watering can and the later, a hoop, and you can see changes in both the palette and brushstroke. https://t.co/vqDBsJpJAU
By the time Renoir painted “Girl with a Hoop” in 1885, he had ceased to exhibit with the impressionist group. https://t.co/0gFcfXBYnJ

Standing on a garden path on a brightly lit day, this little girl is a symphony in red, green, and blue. From her rosy cheeks and red hair bow, set against the green of the grass, to the deep blue of her dress and boots, Renoir dazzles us with this celebration of color and light. https://t.co/h7NevYPsx1

A perennial favorite of Gallery-goers is Renoir’s painting “A Girl with a Watering Can.”
 
Along with “Girl with a Hoop,” these works by Renoir came to the Gallery in 1963 as part of Chester Dale bequest. https://t.co/kaC77I6vKv

While the figure of the dancer posed in fifth position dominates the canvas, it is the virtuoso brushwork that takes center stage. Against a backdrop of loosely defined strokes of blues and greens, the dancer’s skirt comes alive, surrounding the young girl in a diaphanous cloud. https://t.co/BPhF7E7nVy

“The Dancer” was one of 7 works he submitted to the 1st exhibition of the Société anonyme coopérative des artistes, peintres, sculpteurs, graveurs, in April 1874. While many works were met with criticism, this painting was praised for its realism and originality of conception. https://t.co/rZokc4JT0v

While landscape painting was the main source of inspiration for most impressionist artists, Renoir never abandoned his love of the figure and returned to it consistently throughout his career. https://t.co/oeA1C2Daqm

She holds up her skirt allowing us a view of the sunlight as it bounces off the fabric and dances across the river. With his lively brushstroke and explosion of color, Renoir captures the brilliance of a beautiful afternoon spent enjoying good weather and good company. https://t.co/xR0BRsOgrc
Fashionably dressed and standing directly behind Caillebotte is almost certainly Aline Charigot, a favorite model, and Renoir’s future wife. https://t.co/HT17LmVe6r

The figure seated in the boat, dressed in the typical boating costume of white shirt, flared tie, and straw hat is often identified as the artist’s brother, Edmond.

To his left, standing on the bank, is believed to be the painter Gustave Caillebotte, an avid boatman. https://t.co/GHeqnNTKqK

In Renoir’s “Oarsmen at Chatou,” painted in 1879, we see what would have been a familiar scene to the artist and his contemporaries. 

In fact, three of the four main figures in the painting are all believed to be friends of the artist. https://t.co/cPgU9w1ua6

In addition to being the scene of the Gallery’s “Oarsmen at Chatou,” Renoir also painted his friends relaxing on the balcony of the restaurant in “Luncheon of the Boating Party” at the @PhillipsMuseum. https://t.co/2Ph9mmy6oP

Sitting on the bank was the Maison Fournaise, a restaurant and small hotel, which also operated a boat rental concession. It was a frequent meeting place for Impressionists painters, and Renoir depicted it in several of his paintings. https://t.co/vLN6rzgkZ7

Just nine miles west of Paris and easily accessible by train, Chatou was another popular destination for Parisian day-trippers. Its location was ideal for a variety of leisure activities, including swimming, promenading, and, of course, boating. https://t.co/0pw7p8OgZP

As the rowers zigzag across the canvas in a bold, diagonal rhythm, they convey a sense of movement, a progression of time and space that reveals Caillebotte's interest in photography. https://t.co/KdzylPXRoc

In “Skiffs,” exhibited in 1879 at the 4th impressionist show,  he adopted the short, broken brushstrokes of Monet and the bold palette of Renoir, but achieved a much different effect. https://t.co/BCCRJeSxwF
Between 1877 and 1878, Caillebotte made a series of paintings focusing on swimmers, fishermen, rowers, and canoers at his family estate in Yerres. https://t.co/XD7QM4pXal

Often referred to as the unknown impressionist, Gustave Caillebotte's association with the group also began in 1874. While he did not exhibit in their first exhibition, he served as one of the organizers of later shows, as well as promoter and patron. https://t.co/YfKbjAxBwX

Transcribing the fleeting effects of light and atmosphere using distinct brushstrokes of brilliant color, Monet creates a balanced composition repeating the blues, greens, yellows and whites in both the man-made and natural surroundings. https://t.co/oUjbV6OKzF

Their first exhibition occurred in 1874, the same year as this painting, "The Bridge at Argenteuil." In it we see some of the characteristics that came to define works by the Impressionists. https://t.co/1ogJ8Z4W0Z

On May 7, 1873, many of these same artists issued a press release from Monet’s living room, stating the group’s intention to exhibit their artworks independently.  

[Auguste Renoir, “Claude Monet,” 1872] https://t.co/5THNctwzrV

Monet moved to the town in December 1871 and stayed for about six years. During this time, he was extremely prolific. Visitors such as Caillebotte, Cézanne, Degas, Manet, Pissarro, Renoir, and Sisley, came not only to paint, but to share their ideas for and about painting. https://t.co/wSYeAsadpG

Argenteuil, became synonymous with the pioneering group of artists soon to be dubbed the impressionists. Only a 15 min. train ride from Paris, the town was rich in industry and leisure activities, and came to epitomize the expression of modern life the artists wished to capture. https://t.co/FUkAZJevTs

By 1870, France’s railway system was virtually complete. With all lines radiating out from Paris, the cities and surrounding suburbs grew in popularity as travelers made their way from the capital to towns along the scenic stretch of the river Seine. https://t.co/aC1BnedN4H
Many of the paintings here are set in small towns along the Seine—Argenteuil, Chatou, Vétheuil—where the artists lived and worked. https://t.co/87POf4Hcqs

Stepping into this gallery is like opening a door and walking outside on a bright, sunlit summer’s day. With their focus on direct observation and visual effects, Impressionist artists were devoted to capturing the life they saw around them. https://t.co/YBGBGK7sj8
Our tour is led (from home) by Michelle Bird, a curatorial associate in our department of French paintings. https://t.co/OwIGZYbNm2

Today’s tour features works by some of Impressionism’s most beloved artists: Monet, Renoir, and Caillebotte. These paintings can be found in gallery 85 on the Main Floor of the West Building. #MuseumFromHome
 
See all the works in the gallery: https://t.co/g8cUNoBntC https://t.co/LioaBTd78x

For today’s #MuseumMomentofZen, Georgia O’Keeffe’s “Shell No. I,” from 1928. https://t.co/hw564RYboO

Although not a household name, Waitzkin had connections to numerous art movements, and her work was admired by many New York-based artists and poets. Her friends included Allen Ginsberg, Jackson Pollock, Louise Nevelson, Yayoi Kusama, and more.

[“Faces on Mirror,” c. 1985] https://t.co/7hJSzlHt3t

The artist’s son, author @FredWaitzkin, has said: “Stella was charming, enigmatic, and sometimes very dark—like her work. She insisted that great art had to be raw and emotional—never neat or pretty.”

📷: Waitzkin Memorial Library Trust https://t.co/j2rZ5vzFSu

Her Jewish heritage informs “‘Little’ Shoah” (c. 1984), a work about the Holocaust. Waitzkin only made two sculptures about the Holocaust—the other is a larger work titled “Yom Ha Shoah” (c. 1978-1983) (Holocaust Remembrance Day), and is located at the Boris Lurie Art Foundation. https://t.co/rJhXSfgQ5H
The sculptures by Waitzkin in this wall case illustrate the variety of objects that inspired Waitzkin—from books, to a wooden frame, to an antique mirror. https://t.co/tXOFxxUS8i

Her living space was a work of art in itself. See more images of Waitzkin’s eclectic apartment, and a video about her home: https://t.co/L6nYMTya9i 

📷: Waitzkin Memorial Library Trust, photograph by Norman McGrath https://t.co/GgyevsOsfs

A bit of a recluse, she worked out of her apartment in Manhattan’s Chelsea Hotel. Her apartment doubled as her art studio, and her walls were covered with bookshelves, all filled with her resin-cast books and other sculptures.

📷: Waitzkin Memorial Library Trust https://t.co/CV93Ok1JKB

Waitzkin was interested in books as objects. She frequently made resin casts of leather-bound volumes, which she then assembled in small stacks like this one, as well as massive “libraries.”

[“Untitled (Stack of Books),” c. 1980] https://t.co/LbmHvPeHkV

Stella Waitzkin began as an abstract expressionist painter—in the 1950s she studied with Willem de Kooning and Hans Hofmann. By the 1970s, she shifted her focus to polyester resin sculpture, while also working in glass, performance, and film.

📷: Waitzkin Memorial Library Trust https://t.co/de8cMKxatj

Across the room you will find three resin and found object sculptures made during the 1980s by the innovative artist Stella Waitzkin.

These sculptures were given to the Gallery in 2019 by the Waitzkin Memorial Library Trust. 2020 is the centennial of the artist’s birth. https://t.co/o4z1lXDlXK

Cornell used these items as both inspiration and materials for his art.

Learn how to make your own Cornell-inspired box: https://t.co/TMnk161kw3

["Les constellations voisines du pôle," 1961] https://t.co/0JJcLOfekt

You can find some of this material in the Joseph Cornell Study Center at @americanart and @ArchivesAmerArt: https://t.co/f91Yp9axqg 

[Envelope containing leaves, flowers, and a feather collected by Joseph Cornell dated August 4, 1949] https://t.co/it8CAXgILT

The case includes three works by Joseph Cornell, an artist who used collage and found objects to construct unique box sculptures. Cornell collected thousands of printed images, text ephemera, and 3D objects, which he found in antique stalls and bookshops, among other places. https://t.co/dS0immD9Lw
Here you will find works by Yayoi Kusama, Lee Bontecou, Joseph Cornell, Barbara Hepworth, Betye Saar, and even a small Georgia O’Keeffe! https://t.co/IEXmV2Uxkv

In this gallery, you can find art that was made throughout the 20th century, in the spirit of Dada and Neo-Dada. The works in the wall cases were made as early as 1928 and as late as 1988. Let’s start with the east wall case. https://t.co/pHfog8viZu

In contrast, the term “Neo-Dada,” or “New Dada,” was coined during the late 1950s. It was used by art critics to describe a new generation of artists who merged painting and assemblage techniques, often incorporating found objects, much like the earlier Dada artists. https://t.co/ivrJXzu2xF

The name “Dada” was plucked from a dictionary in Zurich in 1916. It means rocking horse in French; “yes yes” in Romanian and Russian; or nothing at all.

[Theo van Doesburg and Kurt Schwitters, “Kleine Dada Soirée (Small Dada Evening),” 1922] https://t.co/BFhvVX5kfF

Today’s tour will focus on the Dada and Neo-Dada half of the room.

The Dada movement began in the wake of World War I. Repulsed by the carnage of the war, these artists celebrated absurdity and chance, and discarded all previous artistic conventions. https://t.co/pt53le7ESI

Our tour is led (from home) by Emily Ann Francisco (@Em_Francisco), a curatorial assistant in our department of modern and contemporary art.

Here’s Emily giving a talk in this space at a past #NGANights. https://t.co/D4sjrUdSRd

Today we will look at several smaller artworks located in two wall cases in the East Building. These two cases can be found in gallery 415B, which displays our Surrealist, Dada, and Neo-Dada artworks. #MuseumFromHome

See all the works in gallery 415B: https://t.co/zvk45zczlK https://t.co/DgoLgl75NQ

Dorothea Lange was born in Hoboken, NJ, on May 26, 1895. On the 125th anniversary of her birth, take a break and explore 160+ photographs by Lange in our collection: https://t.co/l99CTQhyGR 

["Filipinos cutting lettuce, Salinas Valley, California," June 1935] https://t.co/uZVGO5U8RM
For today’s #MuseumMomentofZen, Augustus Saint-Gaudens’ “Early Study of the Allegorical Figure for the Shaw Memorial” (1880). https://t.co/D3pmwAmwWa
Thanks for joining us on #MemorialDay, as we thank the brave men and women who serve our country and remember those who have died while serving. https://t.co/yTy2qJWlva
As part of an extensive conservation and casting project, this plaster version of Saint-Gaudens’s masterpiece came to the Gallery on long-term loan in 1997. https://t.co/ZrWKMurzJA

In 1901, the plaster traveled to the Pan-American Exposition and was purchased the following year by the @buffartsacademy. Presented by that museum to the Saint-Gaudens National Historic Site in 1949, it was exhibited there for several decades. https://t.co/VmPXiIQYnt

Even while working on the bronze version for Boston, Saint-Gaudens was working on another version of the subject. 

This slightly different design, exhibited at the Gallery, is cast in plaster and reflects subtle changes made by the sculptor as he refined the work. https://t.co/nYqX0I1WJr

Two of Shaw’s nephews unveiled the memorial in Boston on Decoration Day, May 31, 1897.

Originally, the monument did not include the 62 soldiers who died in the assault on Fort Wagner. Their names were not added until 1981. https://t.co/knQUwK3tp1

Although the sculptor’s contract called for the work to be finished in two years, it took Saint-Gaudens more than a decade to complete the monument, which kept evolving and growing in complexity, becoming as he said "a labor of love." https://t.co/6gINLeXAwg

The Gallery’s 2013/2014 exhibition “Tell It with Pride” sought to make real the African American soldiers of the 54th by bringing together vintage photographic portraits of them.

Read a roster of 1,500 soldiers or officers who served in the 54th: https://t.co/WIHOlMzxSi https://t.co/yILgLOat0O

While Saint-Gaudens’s depiction of Shaw was based on photographs, he hired African American models, not members of the 54th, to pose for the other soldiers. The Gallery’s collection includes several plaster models for their heads. https://t.co/xPtMdsN6vd

The Shaw Memorial was first imagined by the artist as a traditional equestrian monument to Shaw, but at the urging of Shaw’s family, was reworked by Saint-Gaudens to commemorate the troops as well as their leader. 

[“Preliminary sketch for Shaw Memorial,” 1883] https://t.co/Cr474Hu2nI

In post–Civil War America, the unprecedented interest in creating public monuments to the nation’s heroes brought Saint-Gaudens many commissions. The sculptor’s ability to combine startling naturalism with lofty allegory made his work eminently suited to such endeavors. https://t.co/Ak4Y0zljUq

The memorial was never erected though. In 1865, African American businessman Joshua Benton Smith (who had worked for the Shaw family) initiated a new call for the memorial. In 1883, Saint-Gaudens received the commission. 

"Augustus Saint-Gaudens," about 1878-80, @librarycongress https://t.co/YoZhXveYlh

After the battle of Fort Wagner, men of the 54th proposed a memorial to Shaw near the Fort. Shaw's father suggested at that time "The monument, though originated for my son, ought to bear, with his, the names of his brave officers and men, who fell and were buried with him." https://t.co/Qe4suVWB7g

Following the fall of Charleston, South Carolina, on May 1, 1865, members of the 54th Massachusetts regiment attended a parade honoring more than 260 Union soldiers who had died in a Confederate prison. The parade may be the earliest #MemorialDay celebration on record. https://t.co/MeIPMkOrHj

The bravery of the 54th was widely reported, providing a powerful rallying point for African Americans who had longed for the chance to fight for emancipation.

["Sgt. William Carney," ca. 1900, @librarycongress] https://t.co/unpJMmxgSn

Of the approximately 600 men of the 54th who participated, nearly 300 were captured, declared missing, or died from wounds that they received that day. 

[Kurz & Allison, "Storming Fort Wagner, 1890, @librarycongress] https://t.co/xVo2dhpY0b

Commanded by 25-year-old Shaw, on the evening of July 18, 1863, the 54th Massachusetts led the assault upon the nearly impenetrable Fort Wagner, which guarded access to the port of Charleston, South Carolina. Shaw, at the front of the charge, was one of the first to die. https://t.co/6aj6Z9fC8O

The 54th Massachusetts Volunteer Infantry was raised shortly after Lincoln’s issuance of the Emancipation Proclamation in 1863. Recruits came from many states, encouraged by such African American leaders as Frederick Douglass, whose own sons joined the 54th. https://t.co/PAeo1F8ZXY

May 30th was the originally designated date because there were no anniversaries of battles on that day. A monument to Logan designed by Franklin Simmons and Richard Morris Hunt stands at the center of DC’s Logan Circle. https://t.co/lcvxXdMq7u

Before it was known as #MemorialDay, the nation celebrated Decoration Day. John A. Logan, Commander and Chief of the Union’s veteran group called the Grand Army of the Republic, initiated the holiday, urging Americans to decorate the graves of the dead with flowers. https://t.co/PHLNokmiue

The memorial commemorates the valiant efforts of Colonel Robert Gould Shaw and the men of the 54th Massachusetts, the first Civil War regiment of African Americans enlisted in the North.

The version in Boston Common was dedicated as a monument on Decoration Day on May 31, 1897. https://t.co/SN5ibA8qlV

On #MemorialDay, we honor the lives of soldiers who have died while serving in the US Armed Forces. Today, we will remember them with a look at Augustus Saint-Gaudens’s “Shaw Memorial” (1900). #MuseumFromHome

Read more about the Memorial: https://t.co/2UhExVxhIE https://t.co/f5FsAQNZ4u

And for today’s #MuseumMomentofZen, Binh Danh’s daguerreotype, “Lower Yosemite Falls, Yosemite, CA, October 13, 2011.” https://t.co/eGZwG0oUFn

Ahead of #MemorialDay, Binh Danh’s work is a poignant remembrance of fallen soldiers.

Listen to a conversation between Danh and Robert Schultz about their “War Memoranda” exhibition, which probed the question, “How do Americans remember war?” https://t.co/CHRTMx8lMk https://t.co/xkKe5egjrK
In one view, Danh shows the hillside covered in crosses, the cumulative death toll made apparent by the crowded symbols—too many to count individually. https://t.co/LdwqdugHop

Employing the complex daguerreotype process, Danh pictures individual crosses (or in one case, a Star of David), capturing the names and personal items affixed by different citizens. https://t.co/NT0zit1tgw
